goFarm GoFarm is a perfect solution which offer end to end agriculture services to Indian farmers with an aim to improve the efficiencies of agriculture value chain.\nGoFarm connects farmers all over India to their various needs – Seeds, fertilizers, equipment, crop advisory, bank loans, government schemes and market linkage through a wide network of trained micro entrepreneurs.

//pmfby Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY) aims at supporting sustainable production in agriculture sector by way of - \n a) Providing financial support to farmers suffering crop loss/damage arising out of unforeseen events\n b) Stabilizing the income of farmers to ensure their continuance in farming\n c) Encouraging farmers to adopt innovative and modern agricultural practices\n d) Ensuring flow of credit to the agriculture sector; which will contribute to food security, crop diversification and enhancing growth and competitiveness of agriculture sector besides protecting farmers from production risks.
The PMFBY was launched in 2016 and replaces all the prevailing yield insurance schemes in India. The scheme has been launched with an impetus on crop sector.\n The scheme has extended coverage under localized risks, post-harvest losses etc. and aims at adoption of technology for the purpose of yield estimation. Through increased farmer awareness and low farmer premium rates the scheme aims at increasing the crop insurance penetration in India.
https://pmfby.gov.in/
//pmksy Launched on 1st July, 2015 with the motto of "Har Khet Ko Paani", the Pradhan Mantri Krishi Sinchayee Yojana (PMKSY) is being implemented to expand cultivated area with assured irrigation, reduce wastage of water and improve water use efficiency.\nPMKSY not only focuses on creating sources for assured irrigation, but also creating protective irrigation by harnessing rain water at micro level through "Jal Sanchay" and "Jal Sinchan". Micro irrigation is also incentivized through subsidy to ensure "Per drop-More crop". PMKSY will be supervised and monitored by an Inter-Ministerial National Steering Committee (NSC) will be constituted under the Chairmanship of Prime Minister with Union Ministers from concerned Ministries. A National Executive Committee (NEC) will be constituted under the Chairmanship of Vice Chairman, NITI Aayog to oversee programme implementation, allocation of resources, inter ministerial coordination, monitoring and performance assessment, addressing administrative issues etc.
• Achieve convergence of investments in irrigation at the field level (preparation of district level and, if required, sub district level water use plans).\n • Enhance the physical access of water on the farm and expand cultivable area under assured irrigation (Har Khet Ko Pani).\n • Integration of water source, distribution and its efficient use, to make best use of water through appropriate technologies and practices.\n • Improve on - farm water use efficiency to reduce wastage and increase availability both in duration and extent.\n • Enhance the adoption of precision - irrigation and other water saving technologies (More Crop Per Drop).\n • Enhance recharge of aquifers and introduce sustainable water conservation practices.\n • Ensure the integrated development of rainfed areas using the watershed approach towards soil and water conservation, regeneration of ground water, arresting runoff, providing livelihood options and other NRM activities.\n • Promote extension activities relating to water harvesting, water management and crop alignment for farmers and grass root level field functionaries. \n • Explore the feasibility of reusing treated municipal waste water for peri-urban agriculture.\n
https://pmksy.gov.in/
//kcc This scheme was launched to provide timely and adequate credit to farmers to meet their production credit needs (cultivation expenses) besides meeting contingency expenses, and expenses related to ancillary activities through simplified procedure facilitating availment of the loans as and when needed. The scheme aims at providing adequate and timely cred it for the comprehensive credit requirements of farmers under single window for their cultivation and other needs as indicated below:\n • To meet the short term credit requirements for cultivation of crops\n • Post harvest expenses \n • Produce Marketing loan \n • Consumption requirements of farmer household\n • Working capital for maintenance of farm assets, activities allied to agriculture, like dairy animals, inland fishery and also working capital required for floriculture, horticulture etc.\n • Investment credit requirement for agriculture and allied activities like pump sets, sprayers, dairy animals, floriculture, horticulture etc\n • Short term credit requirements of rearing of animals, birds, fish, shrimp, other aquatic organisms, capture of fish.\n
https://www.sbi.co.in/portal/web/agriculture-banking/kcc
//rgm Rashtriya Gokul Mission (RGM) has been launched in December 2014 with an outlay of Rs 2025 crore for development and conservation of indigenous breeds through selective breeding in the breeding tract and genetic upgradation of nondescript bovine population.\n The scheme comprises of two components namely National Programme for Bovine Breeding (NPBB) and National Mission on Bovine Productivity (NMBP). ➢ Development and conservation of indigenous breeds.\n➢ Breed improvement programme for indigenous breeds so as to improve the genetic makeup and increase the stock\n➢ Enhancing milk production and productivity of bovine population by increasing disease free high genetic merit female population and check on spread of diseases\n➢ Upgrading nondescript cattle using elite indigenous breeds like Gir, Sahiwal, Rathi, Deoni, Tharparkar, Red Sindhi\n➢ Distribution of disease free high genetic merit bulls for natural service\n➢ To bring all breedable females under organised breeding through AI or natural service using germ plasm of high genetic merits\n➢ To arrange quality Artificial Insemination (AI) services at farmers’ doorstep\n➢ To create e-market portal for bovine germplasm for connecting breeders and farmers \n➢ To increase trade of livestock and livestock products by meeting out sanitary and phyto sanitary (SPS) issues\n➢ To select breeding bulls of high genetic merit at a young age through application of genomics.
http://dahd.nic.in/rashtriya-gokul-mission
//shcs A Soil Health Card is used to assess the current status of soil health and, when used over time, to determine changes in soil health that are affected by land management.\n A Soil Health Card displays soil health indicators and associated descriptive terms. The indicators are typically based on farmers\' practical experience and knowledge of local natural resources. The card lists soil health indicators that can be assessed without the aid of technical or laboratory equipment.\n Soil Health Card (SHC) is a Government of India\'s scheme promoted by the Department of Agriculture and Co-operation under the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers\' Welfare. It is being implemented through the Department of Agriculture of all the State and Union Territory Governments. Soil Health Card Scheme is a very beneficial scheme for farmers. There are many farmers in India. And they do not know which types of crops they should grow to get maximum yield. Basically, they do not know the quality and the type of their soil. They might know by experience what crops grow and what crops fail. But they don\'t know what they can do to improve the condition of the soil.
• The scheme will monitor the soil of the farmers well and will give them a formatted report. So, they can decide well which crops they should cultivate and which ones they should skip.\n • The authorities will monitor the soil on a regular basis. One in every 3 years, they will provide a report to farmers. So, farmers need not worry if the nature of the soil changes due to certain factors. Also, they will always have updated data about their soil.\n • The work of the government does not stop at listing down measures required to improve the quality of the soil. In fact, they will also employ experts to help farmers in carrying out the corrective measures.\n • Farmers will get a proper soil health record, thanks to the Soil Health Card Scheme. Also, they can study the soil management practices. Accordingly, they can plan the future of their crops and land.\n • Generally, in government schemes, the person carrying out the study for a particular farmer gets changed. But in the Soil Health Card Scheme, the government is paying attention that the same person carries out soil analysis for a farmer. This will further enhance the effectiveness of the scheme.\n • The soil card will give the farmers a proper idea of which nutrients their soil is lacking. And hence, which crops they should invest in. they will also tell which fertilizers they need. So, ultimately, the crop yield will see a rise.\n • The main aim behind the scheme was to find out the type of particular soil. And then provide ways in which we can improve it. Even if a soil has some limitations, we can do something to get the most out of it. And that is what the government is trying to do with the help of this scheme.\n
https://soilhealth.dac.gov.in/ Map
